snippet: As oil companies complain of lost revenues, the government is moving forward with plans to build more pipelines of its own.
abstract: Canadian officials and companies are desperately seeking alternatives to get the country’s nearly 200 billion barrels in oil reserves to market from landlocked Alberta, as the United States continues to play political ping-pong with the fate of the Keystone XL pipeline; to hasten development of new export routes, the Conservative government is streamlining permit processes and has also threatened to revoke the charitable status of environmental groups that are challenging the projects.
lead_paragraph: As oil companies complain of lost revenues, the government is moving forward with plans to build more pipelines of its own.

headline.seo: Canada Seeks New Ways to Get Oil Reserves to Market
headline.main: Canada Seeks Alternatives to Transport Oil Reserves
headline.print_headline: Canada Seeks Alternatives To Transport Oil Reserves
